message_1:
Suppose we have a data set consisting of the following variables:

Variable 1: 10, 12, 8, 9, 11, 13, 7, 6, 14, 15
Variable 2: 7, 9, 5, 6, 8, 11, 4, 3, 12, 13
Variable 3: 12, 14, 10, 11, 13, 16, 8, 7, 18, 20

Use principal component analysis to determine the number of principal components that would be needed to explain at least 90% of the variation in this data set.
message_2:
To determine the number of principal components needed to explain at least 90% of the variation in this data set, we will follow these steps:

1. Standardize the data.
2. Calculate the covariance matrix.
3. Calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix.
4. Determine the proportion of variance explained by each principal component.
5. Select the number of principal components that explain at least 90% of the variation.

Step 1: Standardize the data
First, we need to standardize the data by subtracting the mean and dividing by the standard deviation for each variable.

Variable 1: (10, 12, 8, 9, 11, 13, 7, 6, 14, 15)
Mean: 10.5, Standard deviation: 2.8722813232690143
Standardized Variable 1: (-0.174, 0.522, -0.870, -0.522, 0.174, 0.870, -1.218, -1.566, 1.218, 1.566)

Variable 2: (7, 9, 5, 6, 8, 11, 4, 3, 12, 13)
Mean: 7.8, Standard deviation: 2.8712813232690143
Standardized Variable 2: (-0.278, 0.417, -0.973, -0.628, 0.069, 1.112, -1.319, -1.674, 1.467, 1.822)

Variable 3: (12, 14, 10, 11, 13, 16, 8, 7, 18, 20)
Mean: 12.9, Standard deviation: 4.00374917893064
Standardized Variable 3: (-0.225, 0.275, -0.725, -0.475, 0.025, 0.775, -1.225, -1.475, 1.275, 1.775)

Step 2: Calculate the covariance matrix
Using the standardized variables, we can calculate the covariance matrix:

|  1.000  0.857  0.946 |
|  0.857  1.000  0.892 |
|  0.946  0.892  1.000 |

Step 3: Calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix
Eigenvalues: λ1 = 2.738, λ2 = 0.230, λ3 = 0.032
Eigenvectors: v1 = (0.577, 0.577, 0.577), v2 = (-0.707, 0.707, 0.000), v3 = (0.408, -0.408, 0.816)

Step 4: Determine the proportion of variance explained by each principal component
Total variance = λ1 + λ2 + λ3 = 2.738 + 0.230 + 0.032 = 3.000
Proportion of variance explained by PC1 = λ1 / Total variance = 2.738 / 3.000 = 0.913
Proportion of variance explained by PC2 = λ2 / Total variance = 0.230 / 3.000 = 0.077
Proportion of variance explained by PC3 = λ3 / Total variance = 0.032 / 3.000 = 0.011

Step 5: Select the number of principal components that explain at least 90% of the variation
Since the first principal component (PC1) explains 91.3% of the variation, which is greater than 90%, we only need 1 principal component to explain at least 90% of the variation in this data set.
